data.title: The Calendar (1948)
data.meta_description: The favourite for the big race is nobbled and suspicion falls on the owner. His secret admirer proves it wasn't him.
data.text:
Arthur Crabtree’s British drama in which a racehorse owner becomes involved in a scandal after losing his money and his fiancée. Starring Greta Gynt, John McCallum and Raymond Lovell.

Adapted from the play and novel of the same name by Edgar Wallace, which were written in 1929 and 1930 respectively, the story concerns the most popular for the big horse race who is bribed and suspicion cascades on the owner. His clandestine enthusiast attempts to verify that it was not him.

John McCallum gives an okay performance in his role as Garry Anson, the man whose life is going badly and it is not going to get any better for him as he has something serious to deal with.

Elsewhere,…

God, this is dull. It seemed much longer than its 79 minutes. A story about racehorses and their owners and trainers. (This is the third British film I’ve seen about racehorses and their human milieu over the past year or so and they’ve all depicted the humans as an insufferably boring lot: this might be socially accurate, but it makes dull cinema.) It is based on a play by Edgar Wallace: Wallace adapted his play into a novel and then came this film. The play and novel are generally regarded as thrillers, but the film is a tame melodrama. John McCallum is the horse owner…and he has money problems. Sonia Holm is his trainer…and there are hints of romance. But…
